title: PyTorch: Model class definitions are not persisted with saved/logged models
body:
### Describe the problem

PyTorch supports an inheritance-based approach for defining custom models (similar to our new `pyfunc.PythonModel` class). Users extend a base class and override method(s) to define the behavior of their model. 

When PyTorch saves the model subclass via [torch.save](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/torch.html#torch.save), it uses the standard Python pickle library. This library does not capture the class definition itself; therefore, the model cannot be reloaded in a a new context unless the class is re-defined or imported.

Our current `mlflow.pytorch.save_model` and `mlflow.pytorch.log_model` APIs do not provide a mechanism for persisting the class definition with the saved model. I've also tried using `cloudpickle` as the serialization module by specifying the `pickle_module` parameter of [torch.save](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/torch.html#torch.save). However, this does not seem to solve the deserialization problem.

### Source code / logs

Step 1: Log a model using the following code from our own `mlflow.pytorch.log_model` example snippet:

```
# X data
x_data = torch.Tensor([[1.0], [2.0], [3.0]])
# Y data with its expected value: labels
y_data = torch.Tensor([[2.0], [4.0], [6.0]])
# Partial Model example modified from Sung Kim
# https://github.com/hunkim/PyTorchZeroToAll
class MyPyTorchModel(torch.nn.Module):
   def __init__(self):
      super(MyPyTorchModel, self).__init__()
      self.linear = torch.nn.Linear(1, 1)  # One in and one out
   def forward(self, x):
       y_pred = self.linear(x)
       return y_pred
# our model
pytorch_model = MyPyTorchModel()
criterion = torch.nn.MSELoss(size_average=False)
optimizer = torch.optim.SGD(pytorch_model.parameters(), lr=0.01)
# Training loop
for epoch in range(500):
   # Forward pass: Compute predicted y by passing x to the model
   y_pred = pytorch_model(x_data)
   # Compute and print loss
   loss = criterion(y_pred, y_data)
   print(epoch, loss.data[0])
   #Zero gradients, perform a backward pass, and update the weights.
   optimizer.zero_grad()
   loss.backward()
   optimizer.step()
# After training
for hv in [4.0, 5.0, 6.0]:
    hour_var = torch.Tensor([[hv]])
    y_pred = pytorch_model(hour_var)
    print("predict (after training)",  hv, y_pred.data[0][0])
# log the model
with mlflow.start_run() as run:
  mlflow.log_param("epochs", 500)
  mlflow.pytorch.log_model(pytorch_model, "pytorch_model", pickle_module=cloudpickle, pickle_protocol=2)
```

2. In a new Python session, load the model using `mlflow.pytorch.load_model`. 

3. Observe the following error:

```
/Users/czumar/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/torch/serialization.pyc in load(f, map_location, pickle_module)
    356         f = open(f, 'rb')
    357     try:
--> 358         return _load(f, map_location, pickle_module)
    359     finally:
    360         if new_fd:

/Users/czumar/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/torch/serialization.pyc in _load(f, map_location, pickle_module)
    540     unpickler = pickle_module.Unpickler(f)
    541     unpickler.persistent_load = persistent_load
--> 542     result = unpickler.load()
    543
    544     deserialized_storage_keys = pickle_module.load(f)

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'MyPyTorchModel'
```
